posts.name: Madeline Darby
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôve recently heard that there is other terminology for ‚Äòslaving‚Äô one motor to another but have had trouble finding this, does anyone know what it is?

Due to the inherent connections to slavery and racism of the terms ‚Äòslave‚Äô and ‚Äòslaving‚Äô, I want to teach the new programming members on my team to use different terminology.
We‚Äôve shifted towards using leader and follower motors. Others I‚Äôve seen: Primary and secondary motor Conductor and follower

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Lead follower is what we go with, except in drivetrains where front=lead and back=follow, so we just use front/back.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked:
Drop the E, just ‚Äúslav motor‚Äù. It‚Äôs cleaner.

slav 660√ó501 102 KB

slav 660√ó501 102 KB

slav 660√ó501 102 KB

Depending on the system terms like primary, main and secondary, auxiliary work

For code I stick to main

For motors I like lead and follower or lead and paired motor.

Whatever you use just make it a standard definition and make sure you‚Äôre consistent.

Funny as it is, renaming it to something that doesn‚Äôt make much sense can cause confusion and more questions. Acronyms and such are great but shy students (e.g. me) won‚Äôt ask what they are and be confused for a while which is probably not ideal.

e.g. I didn‚Äôt know until 2 days ago that when mentors say ‚Äòtrade study‚Äô it means analyzing trade-offs of a specific thing, not studying a trade such as masonry (or as I assumed for my case, designing a complete drivetrain). I had been incorrectly assuming stuff for months.

Edit: I should probably add that I know you don‚Äôt actually intend to call it slav motors.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Leader/follower makes great sense.  Just be sure when you use these terms [especially in writing!] that you either use them as adjectives (or more properly noun modifiers), such as ‚Äúthe follower motor‚Äù or ‚Äúthe leader controller‚Äù, or otherwise provide sufficient context that it is clear that you mean this specific definition of these terms.  This is because, even within mechanical systems, follower can also refer to the thing which interfaces with a cam, and leader can mean so many things, including a bite-resistant segment at the hook end of a fishing line.

Added: I composed this after post number three.  See the post above if you think I‚Äôm being too pedantic.  IMHO, primary/secondary, and conductor are already too overloaded.  Why would you talk about your motor controllers in terms that could be misinterpreted as terms which also refer to [in addition to a myriad of other things] components of your motor?

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
For motors, Lead/Follow is best. The APIs in WPILib for CTRE and Rev both use the word ‚Äúfollow.‚Äù

For reference the ACM (Association for Computing Machinery) has a good article on using inclusive language in code and how we describe it. The article is titled Words Matter and suggests alternatives for a list of troublesome terms.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: When I was working on the design of AC induction motor controllers, I would see references to other controllers (and associated motors) as ‚Äúfollowers‚Äù.

posts.name: Madeline Darby
posts.cooked:
To everyone who‚Äôs responded:

Thanks for all the help! Our team will be using the terminology of leader and follower controllers.
